Meanwhile, Beetle brings Cornelius's frozen body to Grundel and informs him that Thumbelina is going to marry the Mole. After the two leave to stop the wedding, the young jitterbugs thaw Cornelius's body out.
At the wedding, Thumbelina realizes at the last moment that she can't marry someone she does not love and refuses to take the vows. Grundel and Beetle crash the wedding, but Thumbelina flees from them and Mr. Mole. Cornelius intercepts the crowd and confronts Grundel, the ensuing fight resulting in them both falling into an abyss. Once outside and free, Thumbelina is reunited with Jacquimo, who takes her to Cornelius' kingdom, the Vale of the Fairies. Cornelius appears, having survived the fall, the pair are reunited, and Thumbelina accepts his proposal of marriage. The two kiss, and Thumbelina is granted her own wings.
With Thumbelina's mother and the fairy court in attendance, Thumbelina and Cornelius are married and depart on their honeymoon on Cornelius's bumblebee. Images shown during the credits reveal that Beetle resumed his singing career and had gotten his wings back, Ms. Fieldmouse married Mr. Mole, and Grundel also survived the fall with minor injuries and married a female toad (implying that he lost interest in Thumbelina).

A lonely old woman who longs for a child is given a seed by a good witch. When planted, the seed grows into a flower, and inside the blossom is a tiny girl the size of the old woman's thumb. The old woman names the girl Thumbelina and raises her as her own.
Although Thumbelina loves her mother, she craves companionship from someone her own size. One night, Cornelius, the fairy prince, stumbles upon Thumbelina after hearing her beautiful singing. The two take a ride on Cornelius' bumblebee, and fall in love; during this ride Mrs. Toad and her son Grundel are enchanted by Thumbelina's singing. Cornelius promises to return the next day, but after he's gone, Mrs. Toad kidnaps Thumbelina from her bed and takes her away.
Thumbelina awakens on Mrs. Toad's show boat. Mrs. Toad wants Thumbelina to join their troupe and marry Grundel, who is in love with her. They leave Thumbelina alone on a lily pad in order to fetch a priest, but a friendly swallow, Jacquimo (the narrator of the film), overhears Thumbelina's cries for help and frees her. Jacquimo's friends, the jitterbugs, promise to help Thumbelina get home safely while Jacquimo sets off to find Cornelius. Meanwhile, Cornelius learns of Thumbelina's kidnapping and ventures out to find her.
While trying to get home, Thumbelina is ambushed by Berkeley Beetle, who scares the jitterbugs away. He is enamoured with her singing, and promises to show her the way home if she sings at his Beetle Ball first. Thumbelina agrees, but when she's received poorly at the Beetle Ball, Beetle kicks her out without helping her.
Winter is approaching. Jacquimo accidentally impales his wing on a thorn and is knocked out by the cold, while Cornelius falls into a lake and is frozen in ice. Grundel, who is searching for Thumbelina, finds Beetle and discovers she is in love with Prince Cornelius and upon some convincing from Beetle, decides to find and kidnap Cornelius to lure Thumbelina to him. Grundel forces Beetle to help him as Grundel steals his wings and won't return them until Beetle has found and captured Cornelius.
Thumbelina is taken in by Miss Fieldmouse, who tells her that Cornelius has died. The two visit Miss Fieldmouse's neighbor, Mr. Mole who tells them about a dead bird he found in his tunnel earlier that day. It turns out to be Jacquimo, who Thumbelina discovers to be only unconscious. Mr. Mole wishes to marry Thumbelina; heartbroken over Cornelius's death, Thumbelina accepts. Jacquimo awakens under Thumbelina's care and leaves to find Cornelius, refusing to believe that he is dead. Meanwhile, Beetle brings Cornelius's frozen body to Grundel and informs him that Thumbelina is going to marry the Mole. After the two leave to stop the wedding, the young jitterbugs thaw Cornelius's body out.
At the wedding, Thumbelina realizes at the last moment that she can't marry someone she does not love and refuses to take the vows. Grundel and Beetle crash the wedding, but Thumbelina flees from them and Mr. Mole. Cornelius intercepts the crowd and confronts Grundel, the ensuing fight resulting in them both falling into an abyss. Once outside and free, Thumbelina is reunited with Jacquimo, who takes her to Cornelius' kingdom, the Vale of the Fairies. Cornelius appears, having survived the fall, the pair are reunited, and Thumbelina accepts his proposal of marriage. The two kiss, and Thumbelina is granted her own wings.
With Thumbelina's mother and the fairy court in attendance, Thumbelina and Cornelius are married and depart on their honeymoon on Cornelius's bumblebee. Images shown during the credits reveal that Beetle resumed his singing career and had gotten his wings back, Ms. Fieldmouse married Mr. Mole, and Grundel also survived the fall with minor injuries and married a female toad (implying that he lost interest in Thumbelina).

Grundel, who is searching for Thumbelina, finds Beetle and discovers she is in love with Prince Cornelius and upon some convincing from Beetle, decides to find and kidnap Cornelius to lure Thumbelina to him. Grundel forces Beetle to help him as Grundel steals his wings and won't return them until Beetle has found and captured Cornelius.
Thumbelina is taken in by Miss Fieldmouse, who tells her that Cornelius has died. The two visit Miss Fieldmouse's neighbor, Mr. Mole who tells them about a dead bird he found in his tunnel earlier that day. It turns out to be Jacquimo, who Thumbelina discovers to be only unconscious. Mr. Mole wishes to marry Thumbelina; heartbroken over Cornelius's death, Thumbelina accepts. Jacquimo awakens under Thumbelina's care and leaves to find Cornelius, refusing to believe that he is dead. Meanwhile, Beetle brings Cornelius's frozen body to Grundel and informs him that Thumbelina is going to marry the Mole. After the two leave to stop the wedding, the young jitterbugs thaw Cornelius's body out.
At the wedding, Thumbelina realizes at the last moment that she can't marry someone she does not love and refuses to take the vows. Grundel and Beetle crash the wedding, but Thumbelina flees from them and Mr. Mole. Cornelius intercepts the crowd and confronts Grundel, the ensuing fight resulting in them both falling into an abyss. Once outside and free, Thumbelina is reunited with Jacquimo, who takes her to Cornelius' kingdom, the Vale of the Fairies. Cornelius appears, having survived the fall, the pair are reunited, and Thumbelina accepts his proposal of marriage. The two kiss, and Thumbelina is granted her own wings.
With Thumbelina's mother and the fairy court in attendance, Thumbelina and Cornelius are married and depart on their honeymoon on Cornelius's bumblebee. Images shown during the credits reveal that Beetle resumed his singing career and had gotten his wings back, Ms. Fieldmouse married Mr. Mole, and Grundel also survived the fall with minor injuries and married a female toad (implying that he lost interest in Thumbelina).

New Orleans, Louisiana, 1927. A group of enraged men descend into the isolated Seven Doors hotel deep in the marshes. They catch an artist called Schweik (Antoine Saint John), who is cloistered there. Accusing him of being a sorcerer, Schweik is dragged into the cellar where he is savagely beaten with heavy chains, tortured with quicklime acid and crucified with his wrists nailed to a cellar wall, despite his terrible warnings of unleashing evil. Orleans, 1981. Liza Merril (Catriona MacColl) is a young woman who arrives from New York to claim the hotel as an inheritance. Barely the architect friend Marin Avery (Michele Mirabella) begins to show him around the property, strange incidents begin to occur. A painter (Anthony Flees) falls off his platform and is horribly injured, coughing up blood and babbling "eyes, eyes". Dr John McCabe (David Warbeck) arrives to take the injured man to the hospital and offers Liza his sympathy. Next, a plumber named Joe tries to fix a major leak in the flooded basement. However, he is assassinated by a presence that has emerged from behind a thin wall. The hotel's atmosphere is further cooled by the creepy servants, Arthur (Giampaolo Saccarola) and Martha (Veronica Lazar), who apparently come with the hotel. Martha discovers Joe's corpse in the basement and another much older corpse lying in a nearby pool of dirty water. It is apparently that of Schweik, the artist. Walking down the 14 mile causeway to New Orleans, Liza meets a strange blind woman standing in the middle of the desolate road. The blind woman introduces herself as Emily (Sarah Keller) and tells Liza that she was waiting for her, although her eyes are blocked with cataracts. Liza drives Emily to her richly furnished house in New Orleans. Liza is warned by Emily to leave the hotel while she can. Meanwhile in the hospital morgue, Dr. John McCabe performs the autopsy of Joe the Plumber while his assistant Harris (Al Cliver) wants to install an EMG machine on Schweik's corpse. John laughs and leaves for lunch, while Harris stays behind to set up the EMG machine. After Harris leaves on a call, the EMG machine begins to vibrate with activity. Moments later, Joe's wife Mary-Anne (Laura De Marchi) arrives with her daughter Jill (Maria Pia Marsale) to dress her husband's corpse for the funeral, when she is gruesomely murdered by burning with acid. Jill is then threatened by Schweik's resuscitated corpse. Liza meets with John McCabe in a downtown bar to discuss her concerns and fears. He expresses his confusion when Lisa complains about the incompetence of her strange servants. John claims never heard of them, despite knowing everyone in the area. Then comes a call from Harris' bar informing John that Mary-Anne's body was found in the morgue while Jill was found huddled in a corner and scared. Emily Liza returns to the hotel that evening after Joe and Mary-Anne's funeral. Emily tells Liza about the sorcerer Schweik, who stayed in room 36 of the hotel, and about the supernatural underworld that the hotel hides. The hotel was built over one of the seven gates of hell, and Schweik was the guardian. Emily wants to reveal more than wandering her hands to a canvas that shows a bleak vision of lost souls in a terrible and arid landscape. Emily is suddenly afraid that the painting was painted by Schweik before he died, and she runs out of the hotel room into the night. But Liza notices a disturbing fact about her sudden departure: Emily did not step on the bare wooden boards as she ran, and neither did her guide dog. The next day, Liza nervously ventures into room 36, a filthy phantom of sheets. furniture and shafts covered with dusty light. She finds an old book whose strangely meat-like cover has the only word in it

In olden times, England is in turmoil. With the death of the King, noone can decide who is the rightful heir to the throne. With war threatening to tear the country asunder, a stone and anvil appear from the heavens in London town, with a sword planted firmly in the anvil. On the hilt of the sword, read the words, "Whoso pulleth out this sword of this stone and anvil is rightwise king, born of England." Many try to pull the sword, but none can budge it. In time, the sword is forgotten, and the Dark Ages plunge the countryside into a dismal state.Out in the woods one day, Sir Kaye is out hunting with his adopted brother Arthur, whom everyone names 'Wart.' After causing Kaye to miss shooting a deer, Arthur promises to retrieve the arrow. Arthur's journey leads him to a small hut, wherein resides a sorcerer named Merlin, and his pet owl, Archimedes, who can talk. Merlin explains to Arthur that he was expecting him to appear. After they have tea, Merlin decides to accompany Arthur back to his home, and after packing up everything in the hut into a small satchel, the two set off.Arthur and Merlin arrive at the castle of Sir Ector, where Arthur is immediately put to work in the kitchen. Merlin introduces himself to Ector, and displays his powers to the doubting Knight. After some persuasion, Ector allows Merlin to stay, putting him up in the Northwest Tower, a crumbling edifice of the castle.A few days later, Archimedes observes the arrival of Sir Pelinore, who has brought news from London of a jousting tournament to Ector and Kaye. According to the rules, the winner of the tournament will become the new King of England. Ector eagerly begins to have Kaye train, and in his excitement, promises Arthur that if he keeps working hard at his duties, he can become Kaye's squire.Merlin hears of this news, and decides to push Arthur to see his true potential (as Merlin can move into the past and the future, he knows who Arthur will become). While walking outside along the castle's moat, Merlin explains that he can turn into a fish. This idea excites Arthur, and Merline turns them both into fish, to explore the moat. However, a much larger fish soon gives chase to young Arthur, until they both manage to escape.Arthur's tardiness in helping Kaye practice results in him washing dishes. Merlin finds him, and after bewitching the dishes and washing utensils, leads Arthur into the forest, where they both are turned into squirrels by the sorcerer. As Arthur leaps among the trees, he comes across a girl squirrel, who is soon madly infatuated with him. Merlin finds the whole scenario cute, until he is soon found irresistible by another squirrel. Merlin then changes himself and Arthur back to normal. The girl squirrel who was infatuated with Arthur, skitters away, heartbroken.Arthur and Merlin return to the castle, where Ector lectures Merlin for making Arthur shirk his duties. Arthur tries to defend Merlin, but his 'mouthing off' ends causes Ector to declare that Arthur will not become Kaye's squire, and that that honor will belong to another person of the castle, who is named Hobbes.Arthur is dejected at what has happened, but Merlin tries to get him to persevere, and plans to educate Arthur. As he attempts to explain things, Archimedes interjects on Merlin's teaching methods, as Merlin is educating Arthur on things that will not be proven for hundreds of years, and could very well lead people to think of Arthur as a raving lunatic in their current Dark Ages.Exasperated at this lecturing, Merlin turns teaching duties over to Archimedes, while he fiddles with a model plane. Archimedes scoffs at the toy plane, while Merlin attempts to prove that 'man will fly.' His efforts lead to the plane plummeting like a rock to the moat below. Even though the plane's flight was a failure, Arthur tells of how he's often dreamed of soaring like a bird. It is then that Merlin uses his

Brink (Sir Cedric Hardwicke) has recently taken Pud (Bob Watson)'s parents in a car wreck. Brink comes later for Gramps (Lionel Barrymore). Believing that Brink is an ordinary stranger, the cruel old Gramps Mr. Brink orders the property. Pud comes out of the house and asks who the stranger was. Gramps is surprised and relieved that someone else could see the stranger; he was not just a dream or revelation. Pud tells Gramps that when he does a good deed, he will be able to make a wish. Because his apples are constantly being stolen, Gramps wants everyone who climbs up his apple tree to stay there until he allows them to climb down. Pud inadvertently tests the desire when he has trouble getting down from the tree himself, and is only free when Gramps says he can. Pud's busy aunt Demetria (Eily Malyon) designs Pud and the money his parents left him. Gramps spends a lot of time averting the work of adopting the boy. Brink takes Grandma Nellie (Beulah Bondi) to a peaceful death just after she finishes some knitting. When Mr. Brink returns for Gramps, the old man finally realizes who his visitors are. Determined not to leave Pud to Demetria, Gramps urges Mr. Brink to climb the apple tree. While stuck in the tree, he can not take Gramps or anyone else. The only way anyone or anything can die is if they touch Mr. Brink or the apple tree. Demetria plans to have Gramps committed to a psychiatric hospital when he claims that death is trapped in his apple tree. Gramps first proves his story by proving that his doctor, Dr. Evans (Henry Travers), can not even kill a fly they have caught. He gives further proof of his power by shooting Mr. Grimes (Nat Pendleton), the orderly who has come to take him to the asylum; Grimes lives when he should have died. Dr. Evans is now a believer, but he is trying to convince Gramps to betray death so that suffering people can find liberation. Gramps refuses, so the doctor arranges for the local sheriff to commit Gramps while Pud is delivered to Demetria's custody. With the help of the housekeeper (Una Merkel), Gramps tricks both of them into believing that they are planning to go with Mr. Brink when he comes down from the tree. They ask Gramps to convince Brink otherwise, and Demetria promises never to bother Gramps or Pud again. Gramps realizes that sooner or later he will have to fail Brinks - Death is an inevitable part of life in the end. He tries to say goodbye to Pud, who reacts angrily and tries to run away. Mr. Brink sees Pud in the garden and dares him to climb the tree. Pud crosses the fence Gramps built around the tree, but falls and is crippled for life. In dismay, Gramps drops Death from the tree. He takes both Gramps and Pud, who find they can walk again. In the final scene, they walk down a beautiful country road together and hear Grandma Nellie calling them from beyond a brilliant light.

Distraught, Gramps lets death descend from the tree. He takes on both Gramps and Pud, who find they can walk again. In the final scene, they walk down a beautiful country road together and hear Granny Nellie calling them from beyond in a shining light.

Brink (Sir Cedric Hardwicke) recently wrecked Pud's (Bob's Watson) parents in a car wreck. Brink later comes in for Gramps (Lionel Barrymore). Old Gramps thinks Brink is a common stranger and orders Mr. Brink to leave the property. Pud comes out of the house and asks who the stranger is. Gramps is surprised and relieved that someone else could see the stranger; He wasn't just a dream or an apparition. Pud tells Gramps that when he does a good deed, he can make a wish. Since his apples are stolen all the time, Gramps wishes that anyone who climbs his apple tree must stay there until he allows them to climb down. Pud accidentally checks the desire when he's having trouble getting down the tree himself and doesn't get free until Gramps says he can. Pud's busybody aunt Demetria (Eily Malyon) has designs on Pud and the money his parents left him. Gramps spends a lot of time fending off her efforts to adopt the boy. Brink takes Grandma Nellie (Beulah Bondi) to a peaceful death shortly after she knits a little. When Mr. Brink returns to Gramps, the old man finally realizes who his visitor is. Determined not to leave Pud to Demetria, Gramps gets Mr. Brink to climb the apple tree. While in the tree, he cannot take gramps or anyone else. The only way anyone or anything can die is if they touch Mr. Brink or the apple tree. Demetria plans to take Gramps to a mental hospital when he claims death is trapped in his apple tree. Gramps first proves his story by proving that his doctor, Dr. Evans (Henry Travers), can't even kill a fly they've caught. He offers further evidence of his power by shooting Mr. Grimes (Nat Pendleton), the orderly who came to take him to the asylum. Grimes lives when he should have died. Dr. Evans is now a believer, but he tries to convince Gramps to abandon death so that people who are suffering can be set free. Gramps refuses, so the doctor causes the local sheriff to commit Gramps while Pud is being taken into Demetria's custody. With the help of his housekeeper (Una Merkel), Gramps both pretend they should go with Mr. Brink when he comes down from the tree. They ask Gramps to convince Brink otherwise, and Demetria vows never to molest Gramps or Pud again. Gramps realizes that sooner or later he will have to abandon Brinks - death is an ultimately inevitable part of life. He tries to say goodbye to Pud, who reacts angrily and tries to run away. Mr. Brink sees Pud in the yard and dares to climb the tree. Pud gets over the fence Gramps has had built around the tree, but falls and is crippled for life. Distraught, Gramps lets Death down from the tree. He takes both Gramps and Pud, who find they can walk again. In the final scene, they walk together up a beautiful country lane and hear Granny Nellie calling to them from beyond a brilliant light.

Brink (Sir Cedric Hardwicke) has recently taken Pud (Bob Watson)'s parents in a car wreck. Brink then comes for Gramps (Lionel Barrymore). Believing Brink to be an ordinary stranger, the curmudgeonly old grandfather orders Mr. Brink to leave the property. Pud comes out of the house and asks who the stranger was. Grandpa is surprised and relieved that someone else could see the stranger; it was not simply a dream or an apparition. Pud tells Grandpa that when he does a good deed, he can make a wish. Because his apples are constantly being stolen, Grandpa wishes that anyone who climbs his apple tree would have to stay there until he allows them to come down. Pud inadvertently tastes desire when he has trouble getting down from the tree, and is released only when Grandpa says he can. Pud's nosy Aunt Demetria (Eily Malyon) has plans for Pud and the money left by her parents. The grandmother spends a lot of time defending herself against her efforts to adopt the child. Brink leads Granny Nellie (Beulah Bondi) to a peaceful death right after she finishes a bit of knitting. When Mr. Brink returns again for Grandpa, the old man finally realizes who his visitor is. Determined not to leave Pud with Demetria, Grandpa tricks Mr. Brink into climbing the apple tree. While he is trapped in the tree, he cannot take Grandpa or anyone else. The only way someone or anything can die is if they touch Mr. Brink or the apple tree. Demetria plans for Gramps to be admitted to a mental hospital when she claims that Death is trapped in her apple tree. Gramps proves his story first by showing that his doctor, Dr. Evans (Henry Travers), can't even kill a fly they've caught. He offers further proof of his power by shooting Mr. Grimes (Nat Pendleton), the orderly who has come to take him to the asylum; Grimes lives when he should have died. Dr. Evans is now a believer, but tries to convince Grandpa to cheat Death so that suffering people can find deliverance. Grandpa refuses, so the doctor arranges for the local sheriff to turn over Grandpa while Pud is turned over to Demetria's custody. With the help of his housekeeper (Una Merkel), Grandpa tricks them both into believing that they are programmed to go with Mr. Brink when he comes down from the tree. They beg Grandpa to convince Brink otherwise, and Demetria vows never to bother Grandpa or Pud again. Grandpa realizes that sooner or later he will have to disappoint Brinks: death is an inevitable part of life. He tries to say goodbye to Pud, who reacts angrily and tries to run away. Mr. Brink sees Pud in the garden and challenges him to climb the tree. Pud passes the fence that Gramps had built around the tree, but falls and is crippled for life. Distraught, Grandpa lets Death climb down from the tree. He takes both Grandpa and Pud, who discover that they can walk again. In the final scene, they walk together down a beautiful country road and hear Grandma Nellie calling out to them from beyond a bright light.

A Huey helicopter flies over the Alaskan wilderness, its pilots looking for someone below. That someone, Major Mitchell Gant USAF (Rtd) (Clint Eastwood), hears the helicopter approaching and instantly breaks into a dead run back toward his cabin, where he takes a shotgun off its rack and cocks it. As the helicopter lands, Gant lapses into a post-tramautic memory of a nightmare that he lived through in Vietnam: shot down over the North in his A-4, he was being taken to a prison camp when two Hueys machine-gunned his captors. Gant suffered personal trauma when an overflying A-4 dropped an incendiary on the site, killing a little girl who stood around too long, watching the battle. Back in the present, Captain Arthur Buckholz (David Huffman) pulls Gant out of his episode and apologizes for the surprise.The next several scenes are back-and-forth cuts between the conversation between Gant and Buckholz, and a briefing being run by Kenneth Aubrey (Freddie Jones) of the British SIS concerning the Soviet Union's latest fighter/interceptor: the Mikoyan-Gurevich "MiG" Model 31, given the codename "Firefox" by NATO. Its capabilities seem from another world: total stealth, two engines each delivering 50,000 pounds of thrust, combat ceiling of over 100,000 feet, speed above Mach 5 or even Mach 6 (and able to maintain it, no small feat. ), and a weapon and defense system capable of reading the pilot's mind and allowing him to aim and fire his weapons without even having to press a button, giving him a reaction time advantage of 3 to 5 seconds on any opponent. NATO's decision is to send Gant to fly a Firefox prototype right next to the Soviet development base in Bilyarsk, near the Ural Mountains. he was allowed to live on state land which will henceforth be sold under his orders if he does not accept the mission. NATO Air Force Attaché (Thomas Hill) blames him too, as Gant has no experience as a spy and, even worse, is prone to post-stress. traumatic and can crack at any time. They use Gant for only two reasons: He speaks fluent Russian and happens to be a perfect fit for the pressure suit worn by the MiG-31's first test pilot, Lt. Col. Yuriy Voskov (Kai Wulff). retraining, both in flight and in aerial combat, and briefings on his first impersonation - as a corrupt businessman named Leon Sprague, known for smuggling heroin into the Soviet Union. Once his training is complete, he is sent to London where Aubrey gives him his final briefing on his goals and he is disguised with a new haircut and fake mustache. Gant is also familiar with the underground network group, which is mostly made up of Russian Jews. Aubrey also hands him a one-way return device disguised as a cheap transistor radio. What his managers don't tell him, however, is that if anything compromises the mission, Gant will be on his own. - with the "radio". He takes a taxi to his rooms at the Moscow hotel, puts the radio in his pocket and waits. Outside, he sees three Soviet soldiers in formation on patrol. Meanwhile, at the Moscow KGB Center in Dzherzhinskiy Square, KGB Colonel Kontarsky (Kenneth Colley) is finalizing his plans to save the MiG-31 before his next trials. day that will be conducted for the Soviet First Secretary. He also orders his second in command, Dmitri Priabin (Oliver Cotton), to arrest some members of the underground at dawn, but not to move until. Kontarsky actually knows all about the spy ring that routes Bilyarsk's information out of Russia - but even he doesn't know what the CIA and SIS really have planned. precisely 10:30 am with the KGB observing it - it is ordered

On a short trip back to London, serious, bookish bacteriologist Walter Fane (Edward Norton) is blinded by Kitty Garstin (Naomi Watts), a vibrant and vain London socialite.her] mother "), and the couple's honeymoon in Venice. They travel on to Walter's medical post in Shanghai, where he is stationed in a government lab that studies infectious diseases. They find themselves unfit, with Kitty much moreinterested in parties and the social life of British expats. Kitty meets Charles Townsend (Liev Schreiber), a married British vice consul, and the two engage in an underground affair. When Walter discovers his wife's infidelity, he tries to punish her by threatening to divorce her for adultery if she doesn't accompany him to a small village in a remote area of ​​China. He has volunteered to treat the victims of an uncontrolled cholera epidemic that has hit the area. Kitty begs to be able to divorce him quietly, but he refuses, stating "Why should I get into the smallest trouble for you?" She hopes Townsend will leave wife Dorothy and marry her. When he proposes this possibility to Charles, he refuses to accept, even though he previously claimed to love Kitty. She is forced to travel to the mountainous inland region with her husband. They embark on an arduous two-week overland journey, which would be considerably faster and much easier if they traveled by river, but Walter is determined to make Kitty as miserable and uncomfortable as possible. Upon their arrival in Mei-tan-fu, she is distressed to discover that they will live in squalor close by, away from all but their cheerful neighbor Waddington, a British Deputy Commissioner who lives with a young Chinese woman in relative opulence. Walter and Kitty barely speak to each other, and apart from a cook and a Chinese soldier in charge of guarding her, she is alone for long hours. After visiting an orphanage run by a group of French nuns, Kitty voluntarily offers her services and is assigned to work in the music room. She is surprised to learn from the Mother Superior that her husband loves children, especially babies. The police must investigate a series of robberies along a strip of land in the city. The new mayor of the city (Kenneth Mars) assigns Captain Harris (G.W. Bailey) and Lieutenant Proctor (Lance Kinsey) to the case, but while he's at stake, the Wilson gang manages to slip through their fingers. The mayor wants Harris and Proctor to work with Chief of Police Academy Commander Lassard (George Gaynes) to arrest the gang. . Lassard brings together a seven-man team consisting of Hightower (Bubba Smith), Tackleberry (David Graf), Jones (Michael Winslow), Hooks (Marion Ramsey), Callahan (Leslie Easterbrook), Fackler (Bruce Mahler) and Lassard's nephew, Nick (Matt McCoy) who moves from Miami (in the previous film Police Acdemy 5) to the city to stay close to his friends and boring uncle. After spreading flyers about the information about the Wilson gang and getting nowhere, Nick McCoy stumbles upon a piece of paper of an antique diamond on his way to a museum and gets an idea to use it as bait: however, the robbers still ponder the diamond by cutting a hole in it. the truck and escape through the sewer system. McCoy then decides to go undercover to get information about a possible hiding place, but Harris decides to go undercover to get a confession. It turns out that Harris goes undercover like a window washer at a tall building, for which he is afraid of heights, and gets a confession of himself on tape after his loyal but stunned skull, Proctor, accidentally hits him across the balcony. It is revealed here that the robberies are committed by a group of three stupid criminals who do not seem to be able to do this on their own, and it is revealed that they are controlled by a literal shadow figure called "Mastermind", who talks to the three behind a glass wall and uses a voice distortion device. He's planning a plan to get the police out of the way. Commander Lassard and his men are later suspended after stolen jewelry from the latest robbery was planted in Lassard's locker, pending an investigation. The improper police officers decide to clear Lassard's name by grabbing the gang and the principal. By accessing data files from a computer, McCoy concludes that the robberies occur along a bus line and thus intentionally lower the property values ​​in that part of the city. They also learn that someone has to "leak" information to the villains, which is why they are always one step ahead of the police academy. The police academy force finds and fights with the Wilson gang, while Nick chases the leader. A hunt ensues, leading to Commissioner Hurst (George Robertson). It is revealed that the mayor is "Mastermind" and that Captain Harris has inadvertently leaked information during his daily meetings with the mayor. Hurst apologizes and reinstates the force, and a plaque is given to honor the officers' courage the next day. When the film closes, Harris sits in a chair when a string tying the balloon fleet is cut, lifts the chair and floats him up in the air as he shouts Proctor's name.

The movie will start some years in the future from this exact moment. We see advertisements everywhere (buildings, walls, bus stops, etc.) for the hit game Slayers, and how the star character Kable (Gerard Butler) has four more battles before he earns his freedom. We then get to see a fight going on: a massive firefight in a factory. Everyone in the game is controlled by players elsewhere. Characters get points for every kill and for rescuing a teammate. Some characters appear to be performing menial tasks on the battlefield, seemingly oblivious to all the violence around them. 17-year-old Simon (Logan Lerman) plays / controls Kable and walks him through the factory. After slaughtering almost everyone in his way, Kable is blasted outside the factory. Kable manages to run to the safe point to win the battle. Then the remaining characters are transported elsewhere. The other characters congratulate Kable on winning, as he now only has three battles left until he is free. Some of the other characters don't believe anyone will be released from the game. Producer (Michael Weston) and Chief of Staff, Bob, (John de Lancie) of the Gina Parker Smith Show discuss their next guest for the show - hermit genius Ken Castle, creator of Slayers. On the show, Gina (Kyra Sedgwick) talks about Ken Castle's (Michael C. Hall) performance. He first created a game called Society, which is actually a Sims game, but instead of controlling a fake character, the players control a real person and can make them do whatever they want. You can pay to check on someone else, or you can get paid to be checked. The society quickly became extremely popular and profitable, making Castle the richest person in the universe. Nine months ago, Castle created Slayers, a controversial game backed by the federal government. Castle defends Slayers by stating that every character in the game, even though they are real people, are all death row inmates who chose to sign up for the game rather than serve their jail time. If a convict can survive thirty battles, they will be released (although no one has ever survived that long). Some convicts are sent to battlefields with pre-designed actions, and are released if they survive only one battle but are unable to defend themselves (making their death rate extremely high). The games are also all televised on pay-per-view. Everyone in Slayers and Society has had nano-cells implanted in their brains, allowing them to be controlled by someone else. They can only be controlled in the perimeter of the game (meaning that they regain control after the game is over). After the show is over, the signal is hacked by Humanz, a resistance group. The Humanz Brother (Ludacris) condemns Castle and states that we will all be his slaves in the end if we continue down this road. Castle gets a kick out of it and lets his men try to figure out where the signal came from. In prison, a convict kills a guard and tries to escape, but ultimately fails. Kable sits alone and thinks about his family. Freek (John Leguizamo) is sitting next to Kable. He talks about how Kable scares everyone when he sits alone and thinks constantly. He can't believe that Kable has only three battles left. Freek asks him why he is in prison. Kable has a quick flashback of a man bleeding in a room. Later, sitting in his cell, someone opens the slit in the door and gives Kable a picture of his wife and child. The female voice on the other hand knows that his family is all he's fighting for. She has Kable sign a signature for her son David, then takes a blood sample from his hand as proof of authenticity to increase the signature's value. Elsewhere, we see Kable's wife Angie (Amber Valletta) go to work as a character in society. Almost all game characters are dressed in ridiculous and skinny costumes

Early one morning a taxi pulls up at Tiffany & Co.on Fifth Avenue in New York City, from which elegantly dressed Holly Golightly (Audrey Hepburn) emerges. After looking in the shop window, she walks home. Outside her apartment, she averts Sid Arbuck (Claude Stroud), her date from the catastrophicthe night before. Later, she is woken up by her new neighbor Paul Varjak (George Peppard) and rings her doorbell to enter the building. The couple talks as she dresses to leave her weekly visit to Sally Tomato (Alan Reed), a gangsterimprisoned in Sing Sing Prison. Tomato's lawyer, O'Shaughnessy, pays her $ 100 a week to deliver the "weather forecast." Audrey Hepburn as Holly Golightly
As she is leaving for Sing Sing, Holly is introduced to Paul's "decorator", wealthy older woman Emily Eustace Failenson (Patricia Neal), whom Paul nicknames "2E". That night, Holly goes out onto the fire escape to elude an over-eager date (Mel Blanc). She peeks into Paul's apartment and sees 2E leaving money and kissing Paul goodbye. After 2E leaves, Holly enters Paul's apartment and learns that he is a writer who has not had anything published since a book of vignettes five years before. Holly, in turn, explains that she is trying to save money to support her brother Fred when he gets out of the Army. The pair fall asleep, but are awakened when Holly has a nightmare about Fred. She later buys Paul a typewriter ribbon to apologize and invites him to a party at her apartment. There, Paul meets her Hollywood agent, O. J. Berman (Martin Balsam), who describes Holly's transformation from country girl into Manhattan socialite. He is also introduced to JosÃ© da Silva Pereira (JosÃ© Luis de Vilallonga), a wealthy Brazilian politician, and Rusty Trawler (Stanley Adams), the "ninth richest man in America under 50." In the days that follow, Paul and Holly become closer. One day, 2E enters Paul's apartment, worried that she is being followed. Paul tells her that he will investigate and eventually confronts Doc Golightly (Buddy Ebsen), Holly's estranged husband. Doc explains that Holly's real name is Lula Mae Barnes. They married when she was 13, and he wants to take her back to Texas, as Fred will be returning. After Paul reunites Holly and Doc, she tells Paul the marriage was annulled. At the bus station, she tells Doc she is not going with him. Doc leaves broken-hearted. After drinking at a club, Paul and Holly return to her apartment, where she drunkenly tells him that she plans to marry Trawler for his money. A few days later, Paul learns that one of his short stories will be published. On the way to tell Holly, he sees a newspaper headline stating that Trawler has married someone else. Holly and Paul agree to spend the day together, taking turns doing things that each has never done before. At Tiffany's, Paul has the ring from Doc Golightly's box of Cracker Jack engraved as a present for Holly. After spending the night together, he awakens to find her gone. When 2E arrives, Paul ends their relationship. She calmly accepts, having earlier concluded that he and Holly are in love. Holly schemes to marry JosÃ© for his money, which angers Paul. After Holly receives a telegram notifying her of Fred's death, she trashes her apartment. Months later, Paul has moved out. Holly insists she's going to Brazil anyway, asks the car to stop and lets go

The film begins when Alice Melbourne and Judson Ellis arrive in a taxi at a California urban airport, and as they get out of the taxi they tip the driver generously and bribe him not to tell anyone about them. Alice and Judson check the departure sign for The Silver Queen, heading for Panama City, Panama, and appear excited and anxious.Also waiting for the same flight is Peggy Nolan, to whom an expensive flower delivery is made with a cardthanking her for a favor. Peggy dismissively throws the card in the trash and hands the flowers to a woman who sells cheap gardenias. Shortly after, the flight prepares to take off and we are introduced to Professor and Mrs. Spengler, an elderly couple, and Joe, the co-pilot, who is immediately attracted to Alice. Mrs. Spengler is a dominant woman, but her husband seems content to be in charge of a child. While they are waiting on the tarmac near the plane, a car arrives and a well-dressed man appears with a young boy and another man. The boy is Tommy and he is sent away with "Uncle" Pete until his father - a gangster - can later follow. When the passengers board, Bill, the pilot, is informed that they will transport an anarchist back to Panama. , but he assures the group that nothing is wrong, as the man will be in custody during the flight. The prisoner is Vasquez and is accompanied by a bounty hunter named Crimp. After Larry the flight attendant helps everyone settle in, the flight takes off with his twelve souls on board. Bill and Joe discuss plans for the layover and Joe indicates he is interested in Alice. He goes back to the passenger compartment where the beds are made and where people go in for the night - except for Crimp who plans to stay up and make sure Vasquez doesn't "go for a walk" - cheating on the executioner and himself for $ 5,000. Pete puts his young bill in for the night and helps him say his prayers (something Pete is not familiar with). Peggy comes to the cockpit to visit Bill, whose rudeness finally makes it clear that he doesn't want anything to do with her. When Alice calls for the flight attendant, Joe takes the call and plays for her. The next morning the plane arrives for a refueling stop in Mexico and the passengers have breakfast. Joe continues to chase Alice, assuming she is Judson's secretary. Peggy makes another attempt to warm up to Bill and is rejected again. Then Pete tells her that her help is not needed if she tries to get Tommy to drink his milk. Peggy has been 'marked' as a loose woman by her fellow travelers who don't want anything to do with her. Before boarding the plane, a reporter confronts Judson and Alice and Joe discovers that she is engaged to her 'boss' and that they are running away. the flight continues and faces stormy weather. The professor discusses the methods by which a South American tribe of headhunters practice their trade. The conversation is interrupted by a news bulletin detailing how Tommy's father was murdered. Peggy tries to help Tommy again and says "he needs a wife." But Pete is still judgmental, replying "he needs a lady." Mrs. Spengler intervenes and comforts Tommy. As the storm they fly through gets harder, the passengers strap themselves into their seats and Crimp insists that the pilots turn around. As the plane rocks back and forth, a pair of metal cylinders break loose and crash through the back door. Tommy gets dangerously close to the door when Llarry rescues him and hands him over to Pete. At that moment the plane drops sharply and Larry is thrown the door to his death. While Joe and Bill try to stabilize the plane, Crimp tries to force them to turn back by waving his gun at them. In battle, the gun fires and is picked up by Vasquez. With a damaged engine, the Silver Queen crashes and all eleven on board survive. The next morning, Joe and Bill admit to the professor that they have been blown away

Pink is also struck by his overprotective mother, who pampers him by giving him everything he wants. The drugs make Pink hallucinate and he fantasizes that he is a neo-Nazi dictator, his concert is a meeting. His supporters continue to attack ethnic minorities and rape the black man's white girlfriend. Later, Pink holds a meeting in suburban London and sings "Waiting for the Worms". More than a year has passed since the city of Barrow, Alaska, was destroyed by a gang of vampires during its monthly sunset. Grief-stricken over the death of her husband, bound by nightmares and devoid of all emotions but hatred and sadness, Stella (Kile Sanchez) has spent her last months traveling the world trying to convince others that vampires exist in this world. As if she is being hunted, Stella is well aware of the impending threat to her life, the death of her husband Eben has deprived her of the ability to feel emotions, leaving her feeling cold and empty inside. Following the instructions of a mysterious man named Dane, she ends up in Los Angeles. One night, while lecturing in front of an audience of people with whom she hopes to convince that vampires exist and know they are present, when she speaks, she activates an overhead. ultraviolet lamps burning several vampires in the audience in front of humans. She is quickly arrested and pursued by a man named FBI Agent Norris, whom she quickly learns to be an "acquaintance" (insect eater), one of the many thousands of vampire followers around the world tasked with continuing their activities. covered. After they release her from custody with a warning not to disclose the existence of vampires, she returns to her hotel room and finds three people waiting for her; Paul (Rhys Coiro), Amber (Diora Byrd), and Todd (Harold Perrino), whom Dane sent to fetch her to hunt down the vampire queen Lilith, whom they believe will one day be removed from the road, the vampires will fall into more or less a form of inaction. as she is in charge of their every move and keeping them hidden when Stella asks if she is responsible for the incident at Barrow and is notified of it. She is brought in to meet Dane (Ben Cotton) and is shocked to discover that he is also a vampire, although he retains an understanding of humanity due to a superficial wound, only drinking blood from the packed hospital supplies he holds. attacks on the vampire nest, Paul eventually convinces Stella to join them by telling her about his daughter killed by one of them and his accusations of murdering a vampire, which led to a divorce from his wife. Four of them fall into the vampire's nest and end up to ambush a group of them. In an attempt to flee, Todd is bitten and turns after locking themselves in a basement room. When Paul hesitates, Stella manages to kill him by hitting the head with a cinder block. They decide to wait for the night when the vampires go out to eat in order to escape. When night falls, Dane comes and frees them, on their way out they catch a vampire. Dane takes him back to their base of operations and interrogates the non-English-speaking animal vamp with ultraviolet lamps and eventually follows him back to another nest. They invade the nest and rescue a human they used as a feeding station and with her memories of Lilith's lair aboard one of the ships in the bay they are able to plan an attack on her directly. and have sex. Meanwhile, Lilith (Mia Kirshner) decides that Agent Norris must prove his worth to become a vampire (to cure throat or lung cancer from which he suffers) and bites the neck of a captive girl named Stacey (Katharine Isabelle). , drink her blood until she's dead. Then she sends him to hunt Stella and the others. Dane is killed when Norris arrives, and the others flee with the survivor from the nest, they travel to a shipyard, and Jennifer points to the boat that they will sail to Alaska. for another 30 days feeding period. They tell Jennifer to leave and the three stowaways on the ship and discover that vampires can be resurrected after death if their corpses are given human blood. They end up confronting the human captain who says

A lonely old woman longing for a child receives a seed from a good witch. When it is planted, the seed grows into a flower, and in the blossom is a little girl about the size of an old woman's thumb. The old woman calls the girl Thumbelina and raises her as his. Although Thumbelina loves her mother, she craves the company of someone her own size. One night, Cornelius, the fairy prince, runs into Thumbelina after hearing her beautiful song. The two take a ride on Cornelius' hornet and fall in love; during this ride Mrs. Toad and her son Grundel are enchanted by Thumbelina's song. Cornelius promises to return the next day, but after he is gone, Mrs. Toad kidnaps Thumbelina from her bed and takes her away. Thumbelina wakes up in Mrs. Toad's boat. Mrs. Toad wants Thumbelina to join their company and marry Grundel, who is in love with her. They leave Thumbelina alone on a water lily to fetch a priest, but a friendly swallow, Jacquimo (the film's narrator), hears Thumbelina's cries for help and frees her. Jacquimo's friends, the jitterbugs, promise to help Thumbelina get home safely while Jacquimo goes in search of Cornelius. Meanwhile, Cornelius learns of Thumbelina's kidnapping and ventures to search for her. While he tries to get home, Thumbelina is ambushed by Berkeley Beetle, which scares off jitterbugs. He is in love with her with her singing and promises to show her the way home if she sings before her at her Beetle Ball. Thumbelina agrees, but when she is badly received at the Beetle Ball, Beetle throws her out of her without helping her. Winter is approaching. Jacquimo accidentally impales his wing on a thorn and is knocked out by the cold, while Cornelius falls into a lake and is frozen in ice. Grundel, who is looking for Thumbelina, finds Beetle and discovers that she is in love with Prince Cornelius and upon some convincing from Beetle, he decides to find and kidnap Cornelius to lure Thumbelina to him. Grundel forces Beetle to help him while Grundel steals his wings and won't return them until Beetle finds and captures Cornelius. Thumbelina is greeted by Miss Fieldmouse, who tells her that Cornelius is dead. The two visit Miss Fieldmouse's neighbor, Mr. Mole, who tells them about a dead bird she found in her tunnel that day. It turns out to be Jacquimo, who Thumbelina turns out to be just unconscious. Mr. Mole wishes to marry Thumbelina; heartbroken by the death of Cornelius, Thumbelina accepts. Jacquimo wakes up under Thumbelina's care and sets off to find Cornelius, refusing to believe he is dead. Meanwhile, Beetle brings Cornelius' frozen body to Grundel and informs him that Thumbelina is about to marry the Mole. After the two leave to break up the marriage, the young jitterbugs thaw Cornelius's body. At the wedding, she Thumbelina realizes at the last moment that she cannot marry someone she doesn't love and she refuses to take vows. Grundel and Beetle ruin the marriage, but Thumbelina runs away from them and Mr. Mole. Cornelius intercepts the crowd and confronts Grundel, the ensuing fight knocking both of them into an abyss. Once out and free of her, Thumbelina is reunited with Jacquimo, who takes her to the kingdom of Cornelius, the Valley of the Fairies. Cornelius, a survivor of the fall, appears, the two reunite and Thumbelina accepts her marriage proposal. The two kiss, and Thumbelina is granted her own wings. With Thumbelina's mother and the court of fairies present, Thumbelina and Cornelius get married and set off on their honeymoon on Cornelius' bumblebee. The images shown during the credits reveal that Beetle has resumed his singing career and got his wings back, Mrs. Fieldmouse married Mr. Mole and Grundel also survived the fall with minor injuries and married a female toad. (implying that he has lost interest in Thumbelina).

A lonely old woman longing for a child receives a seed from a good witch. When planted, the seed becomes a flower, and inside the flower is a little girl the size of an old woman's thumb. The old woman names the girl Thumbelina and raises her as if she were her own. Although Thumbelina loves her mother, she longs for the company of someone her size. One night, Cornelius, the prince of the fairies, bumps into Thumbelina after hearing her beautiful song. The two ride on Cornelius's bumblebee and fall in love; During this walk, Mrs. Toad and her son Grundel are delighted with Thumbelina's singing. Cornelius promises to return the next day, but after he's gone, Mrs. Toad kidnaps Thumbelina from her bed and takes her away. Thumbelina wakes up on Ms. Toad's show boat. Mrs. Toad wants Thumbelina to join her group and marry Grundel, who has a crush on her. Thumbelina is left alone on a lily pad to go find a priest, but a friendly swallow, Jacquimo (the film's narrator), hears Thumbelina's cries for help and frees her from her. Jacquimo's friends, the jitterbugs, promise to help Thumbelina get home safely while Jacquimo sets off to find Cornelius. Meanwhile, Cornelius finds out about Thumbelina's kidnapping and ventures out to find her. While she is trying to get home, Thumbelina is ambushed by the Berkeley Beetle, who scares the jitterbugs. He is in love with her singing and promises to show her the way home if she sings at her Beetle Ball first. Thumbelina agrees, but when she is badly received at the Beetle Ball, Beetle kicks her out without helping her. Winter is coming. Jacquimo accidentally impales his wing with a thorn and is struck by the cold, while Cornelius falls into a lake and freezes in ice. Grundel, who is looking for Thumbelina, finds Beetle and discovers that she is in love with Prince Cornelius and after Beetle convinces her of her, she decides to find and kidnap Cornelius to lure Thumbelina to him. Grundel forces Beetle to help him while Grundel steals his wings and will not return them until Beetle has found and captured Cornelius. Thumbelina is taken in by Miss Fieldmouse, who tells her that Cornelius is dead. The two visit Mrs. Fieldmouse's neighbor, Mr. Mole, who tells them about a dead bird he found in his tunnel that day. It turns out to be Jacquimo, whom Thumbelina discovers is just unconscious. Mr. Mole wants to marry Thumbelina; heartache over Cornelius' death, Thumbelina accepts. Jacquimo wakes up under Tommelina's care and goes to find Cornelius, refusing to believe that he is dead. Meanwhile, Beetle brings Cornelius' frozen body to Grundel and informs him that Thumbelina is going to marry the mole. After the two leave to stop the wedding, the young jitterbugs thaw Cornelius' body. At the wedding, Thumbelina realizes at the last minute that she cannot marry someone she does not love, and refuses to make the promise. Grundel and Beetle crash the wedding, but Thumbelina escapes from them and Mr. Mole. Cornelius intercepts the crowd and confronts Grundel, the ensuing battle resulted in them both falling into an abyss. Once outside and free, Thumbelina is reunited with Jacquimo, who takes her to Cornelius' kingdom, Vale of the Fairies. Cornelius shows up, after surviving the fall, the couple is reunited, and Thumbelina accepts the proposal of marriage. The two kiss, and Thumbelina gets her own wings. With Thumbelina's mother and the fairy court, Thumbelina and Cornelius are married and go on a honeymoon on Cornelius' hops. Photos shown below the credits reveal that Beetle resumed her singing career and had regained her wings, Fieldmouse married Mr. Mole, and Grundel also survived the fall with minor injuries and married a female toad (suggesting he lost interest in Thumbelina).

Photos shown below the credits reveal that Beetle resumed her singing career and had regained her wings, Fieldmouse married Mr. Mole, and Grundel also survived the fall with minor injuries and married a female toad (suggesting he lost interest in Thumbelina).

A lonely old woman who longs for a child is given a seed by a good witch. When planted, the seed grows into a flower, and inside the blossom is a tiny girl the size of the old woman's thumb. The old woman names the girl Thumbelina and raises her as her own. Although Thumbelina loves her mother, she craves companionship from someone her own size. One night, Cornelius, the fairy prince, stumbles upon Thumbelina after hearing her beautiful singing. The two take a ride on Cornelius' hops and fall in love; During this trip, Mrs. Toad and her son Grundel are enchanted by Thumbelina's song. Cornelius promises to return the next day, but after he's gone, Mrs. Toad kidnaps Thumbelina from bed and takes her away. Thumbelina wakes up on Mrs. Toad's show boat. Mrs. Toad wants Thumbelina to join their squad and marry Grundel, who is in love with her. They leave Thumbelina alone on a lily pillow to fetch a priest, but a friendly swallow, Jacquimo (the film's narrator), hears Thumbelina's cry for help and sets her free. Jacquimo's friends, the jitterbugs, promise to help Thumbelina get home safely while Jacquimo sets off to find Cornelius. Meanwhile, Cornelius finds out about Thumbelina's abduction and dares to find her. While trying to get home, Thumbelina is pushed back by Berkeley Beetle, who scares jitterbugs. He is in love with her songs, and promises to show her the way home if she sings on his Beetle Ball first. Thumbelina agrees, but when she is poorly received at the Beetle Ball, Beetle kicks her out without helping her. Winter is approaching. Jacquimo accidentally impales the wing of a thorn and is knocked out by the cold, while Cornelius falls into a lake and is frozen in the ice. Grundel, who is looking for Thumbelina, finds Beetle and discovers that she is in love with Prince Cornelius, and after some convincing from Beetle, he decides to find and kidnap Cornelius to lure Thumbelina to him. Grundel forces Beetle to help him as Grundel steals the wings and will not return them until Beetle has found and captured Cornelius. Thumb is taken in by Miss Fieldmouse, who tells her that Cornelius is dead. The two visit Miss Fieldmouse's neighbor, Mr. Mole, who tells them about a dead bird he found in his tunnel earlier that day. It turns out to be Jacquimo, whom Thumbelina discovers is just unconscious. Mr. Mole wants to marry Thumbelina; heartache over Cornelius' death, Thumbelina accepts. Jacquimo wakes up under Tommelina's care and goes to find Cornelius, refusing to believe that he is dead. Meanwhile, Beetle brings Cornelius' frozen body to Grundel and informs him that Thumbelina is going to marry the mole. After the two leave to stop the wedding, the young jitterbugs thaw Cornelius' body. At the wedding, Thumbelina realizes at the last minute that she cannot marry someone she does not love, and refuses to make the promise. Grundel and Beetle crash the wedding, but Thumbelina escapes from them and Mr. Mole. Cornelius intercepts the crowd and confronts Grundel, the ensuing battle resulted in them both falling into an abyss. Once outside and free, Thumbelina is reunited with Jacquimo, who takes her to Cornelius' kingdom, Vale of the Fairies. Cornelius shows up, after surviving the fall, the couple is reunited, and Thumbelina accepts the proposal of marriage. The two kiss, and Thumbelina gets her own wings. With Thumbelina's mother and the fairy court, Thumbelina and Cornelius are married and go on a honeymoon on Cornelius' hops. Photos shown below the credits reveal that Beetle resumed her singing career and had regained her wings, Fieldmouse married Mr. Mole, and Grundel also survived the fall with minor injuries and married a female toad (suggesting he lost interest in Thumbelina).
